title: 108_s1902
content: The National Commission on Digestive Diseases was established. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the Director of the National Institutes of Health, will establish a National Commission on Digestive Diseases within 60 days of the enactment of this Act. The Commission's duties include conducting a study on the incidence, duration, morbidity, and mortality rates of digestive diseases, as well as evaluating public and private resources for diagnosis and prevention. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases will develop a long-range plan for research and resources to address digestive diseases, including basic biological processes, epidemiology, and etiology. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases will focus on investigations into the epidemiology, etiology, diagnosis, treatment, prevention, and control of digestive diseases, as well as the development of preventive measures, detection in presymptomatic stages, and criteria for clinical management. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases aims to advance research, clinical management, and education in the field of digestive diseases, including incorporating insights from genomic and proteomic research, developing coordinated healthcare systems, and providing education and training for professionals. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases aims to advance research, clinical management, and education in the field of digestive diseases. The long-range plan includes trials in clinical and translational research, establishment of a surveillance system, and recommendations for funding needed by each National Institutes of Health. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases will prepare estimates for the fiscal year following the completion of their plan and for the next 5 years. The Commission will consist of 16 members, with 10 appointed from scientists by the Secretary. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases will consist of 16 members appointed from scientists, physicians, and health professionals, including clinical gastroenterologists, researchers, surgeons, liver disease experts, epidemiologists, allied health professionals, and basic biomedical scientists. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases will consist of 16 members appointed from various backgrounds, including scientists, physicians, health professionals, and members of the general public with personal experience in digestive diseases. Ex officio members will also be designated from the National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases and other relevant officials. The ex officio members of the National Commission on Digestive Diseases include officials such as the Directors of various institutes like the National Institutes of Health, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases, National Cancer Institute, and others. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases includes ex officio members from various institutes and officials such as the Directors of the National Institutes of Health, National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive Kidney Diseases, National Cancer Institute, and others. The Commission appoints a Chair from its members, with terms lasting the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases appoints a Chair from its members, with terms lasting the life of the Commission. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, with the individual appointed to fill a vacancy serving for the remainder of the predecessor's term. The Commission must meet within 60 days of establishment and at least three times during its existence. Members not affiliated with the Federal Government receive compensation for their duties. Members of the National Commission on Digestive Diseases receive compensation for their duties, with limits on the amount based on government pay scales. Ex officio members who are federal officers or employees cannot receive additional compensation for their service on the Commission. Members are also reimbursed for travel expenses incurred while serving away from their homes or regular places of business. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases compensates its members based on government pay scales and reimburses them for travel expenses. The Commission can appoint an executive director and additional staff as needed. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases has the authority to appoint professional staff, consultants, and hold hearings as necessary. Within 18 months, the Commission must submit a final report to Congress containing a long-range plan, expenditure estimates, and any legislative recommendations. The National Commission on Digestive Diseases evaluates the effectiveness of the Interagency Coordinating Committee for Digestive Diseases and may recommend organizational changes within the National Institutes of Health. The Commission terminates 30 days after submitting the final report to Congress, with an authorization of $4,000,000 for fiscal years 2005 and 2006.
